objdescid.compdate: c. 1780The date of this drawing is based on the "1780" date inscribed on "Albion rose," Blake's etching/engraving of the same design as the sketch on the recto of this drawing. This verso sketch was very probably executed at about the same time as the recto drawing.

provenance.name: Victoria and Albert Museum
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Blake's wife Catherine at his death in 1827; by inheritance to Frederick Tatham upon Catherine Blake's death in 1831; apparently sold by Tatham to the dealer Joseph Hogarth; sold from Hogarth's stock, Southgate and Barrett auction, London, 7 June 1854 and seventeen following days, lot 4180 on the tenth day, with three other works by Blake (6s. to the dealer H. Palser); the dealer E. Parsons; sold by Parsons to the Victoria and Albert Museum in 1881.

desc.objtitle:
Study for "Glad Day," "Albion Rose" or "The Dance of Albion": The Same Figure Seen from Behind,
object 1 (Butlin 73 verso)

objnote.p: The Victoria and Albert accession number is inscribed in pen and ink lower right. For the pencil sketch on the recto, see Study for "Glad Day," "Albion Rose" or "The Dance of Albion".

illustration.illusobjdesc: A single male figure seen from behind stands in the center of this composition. The figure is nude with prominent buttocks and has short curly hair. His head is tilted up and both arms are raised horizontally, turning them so that both wrists face up and palms out. His fingers, which are noticeably long, are spread with thumbs pointing up. The expressiveness of this position may communicate the figure's ecstasy. There are additional lines sketched in and near the palms of both hands, though the representational meaning of these is not clear. They may be alternative positions for the fingers. A small circular object, perhaps a ball(?), is visible above and right of his straightened right leg. This circle may be a later addition not by Blake. The figure raises his left leg, which is bent slightly backward at the knee, at 45 degrees. He points his toes of his left foot to the left where they appear to touch or rest on tiptoe on a serpentine diagonal line that extends from the center of the lower edge of the design (below the figure's right foot) to the left side of the composition by the figure's left hand. This line may indicate a geological form such as the outline of a rocky cliff. A horizontal line bisects the right side of the scene and a semicircular shape, likely a rising or setting sun, is visible above this line. The figure is likely the same character in a different position as the one sketched on the recto of this composition, a preliminary drawing for Blake's etching/engraving, "Albion rose." The figure is not specifically identified as Albion until the inscription added to the plate c. 1820.
